page.title: 05DRAKES LEAT,DEVONPORT LEAT
page.content: At the top of our school field there are remains of the two leats which used to carry water from Dartmoor to Plymouth.In 1591 Drakes Leat was built.Sir Francis Drake supervised the building.It took water from the River Meavy and was 17 miles long. It discharged its water into the sea at Millbay.Later the leat went into Drakes reservoir, near the City Museum.When Burrator Reservoir was built Drakes Leat was no longer needed so it is now dry.As Devonport grew into a town,more water was needed so Devonport Leat was built in 1793.It took water from three rivers, the Cowsic, the Blackabrook and the West Dart. It now flows into Burrator and from there to Plymouth the leat is dry.Burrator Reservoir was built in 1893.Now a new reservoir is planned because Burrator is not big enough.
